'''Cori Dionne''' "'''Coco'''" '''Gauff''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|g|ɔː|f}} {{respell|GAWF}}; born March 13, 2004) is an American professional [[tennis]] player. Gauff has career-high [[Women's Tennis Association|WTA]] rankings of world No. 2 in singles and of [[List of WTA number 1 ranked doubles tennis players|world No. 1]] in doubles. She has won nine [[WTA Tour]] singles titles, including the [[2023 US Open – Women's singles|2023 US Open]] and [[2024 WTA Finals – Singles|2024 WTA Finals]], and nine doubles titles, including the [[2024 French Open – Women's doubles|2024 French Open]].
Gauff made her [[WTA Tour]] debut in March 2019 at the [[2019 Miami Open – Women's singles|Miami Open]] at the age of 15. She received a wildcard into the qualifying draw at the [[2019 Wimbledon Championships – Women's singles|2019 Wimbledon Championships]], where she became the youngest player in the tournament's history to qualify for the main draw. There, she won over [[Venus Williams]] and reached the fourth round. Gauff won her first WTA Tour singles title at the [[2019 Upper Austria Ladies Linz – Singles|2019 Linz Open]]. She reached her first major final in women's doubles at the [[2021 US Open – Women's doubles|2021 US Open]] and reached her first Grand Slam singles final at the [[2022 French Open – Women's singles|2022 French Open]]. In 2023, Gauff won her first [[WTA 1000 tournaments|WTA 1000]] title at the [[2023 Western & Southern Open – Women's singles|Cincinnati Open]] and her first Major singles title at the [[2023 US Open – Women's singles|US Open]].{{TOC limit|2}}

==Early life==
Gauff was born in [[Atlanta, Georgia]]<ref>{{cite web | url=https://abcnews.go.com/GMA/Family/coco-gauff-mom-dad-us-open-victory-speech/story?id=103089045 | title=What to know about Coco Gauff's mom, dad and siblings | publisher=ABC News | accessdate=20 April 2024}}</ref> on March 13, 2004, to Candi ({{Nee|Odom}})<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://heavy.com/sports/2019/07/coco-gauff-mother-candi-mom/|title=Candi Gauff, Coco Gauff's Mother: 5 Fast Facts You Need to Know|last=McBride|first=Jessica|date=July 8, 2019|website=Heavy|access-date=July 10, 2019|archive-date=July 9, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190709204853/https://heavy.com/sports/2019/07/coco-gauff-mother-candi-mom/|url-status=live}}</ref> and Corey Gauff, both from [[Delray Beach, Florida]].<ref name="delray-beach">{{cite web |last1=Persak |first1=Mike |title=Delray's Coco Gauff, 14, stays grounded with family after winning French Open girls' title |url=https://www.sun-sentinel.com/sports/tennis/fl-sp-tennis-coco-gauff-20180618-story.html |website=Sun-Sentinel |date=June 21, 2018 |access-date=7 July 2019 |archive-date=October 13, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181013041017/https://www.sun-sentinel.com/sports/tennis/fl-sp-tennis-coco-gauff-20180618-story.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/life/wimbledon-wunderkind-cori-coco-gauff/|title=So who is Wimbledon wunderkind, Cori 'Coco' Gauff?|last=Cohen|first=Claire|date=July 3, 2019|website=The Telegraph|access-date=July 10, 2019|archive-date=July 8, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190708224501/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/life/wimbledon-wunderkind-cori-coco-gauff/|url-status=live}}</ref> She has two younger brothers.<ref name="nyt-ten">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/03/sports/tennis/cori-gauff-facts-bio-history.html|title=Cori Gauff: 10 Things to Know About the Newest Tennis Phenom|last1=Rothenberg|first1=Ben|newspaper=The New York Times|date=July 3, 2019|access-date=July 7, 2019|archive-date=July 7, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190707015552/https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/03/sports/tennis/cori-gauff-facts-bio-history.html|url-status=live}}</ref> Her father played college basketball at [[Georgia State University]] and later worked as a health care executive. Her mother was a track and field athlete at [[Florida State University]] and worked as an educator.<ref name="undefeated">{{cite web |last1=Bembry |first1=Jerry |title=Coco Gauff and family following familiar path to greatness |url=https://andscape.com/features/coco-gauff-and-family-following-familiar-path-to-greatness/ |website=[[Andscape]] |date=July 5, 2019 |access-date=July 7, 2019 |archive-date=April 30, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220430192950/https://andscape.com/features/coco-gauff-and-family-following-familiar-path-to-greatness/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Gauff lived her early years in Atlanta.<ref name="2009-goat">{{cite web |last1=Maine |first1=D'Arcy |title=Coco Gauff's Wimbledon run is over, but her future remains bright |url=https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/27105815/meet-coco-gauff-15-year-old-everyone-wimbledon-talking |date=July 8, 2019|access-date=7 July 2019 |publisher=ESPN |archive-date=July 4, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190704182018/https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/27105815/meet-coco-gauff-15-year-old-everyone-wimbledon-talking |url-status=live }}</ref> She began playing tennis at the age of six. When she was seven, her family moved back to Delray Beach to have better training opportunities.<ref name="bio">{{cite web |title=Coco Gauff Bio |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/players/player/328560/title/Cori-Gauff#bio |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190728020923/https://www.wtatennis.com/players/player/328560/title/cori-gauff#bio |archive-date=July 28, 2019 |access-date=7 July 2019 |website=WTA Tennis}}</ref><ref name="goat">{{cite web |title=Cori Gauff, 13, Has Great Potential And A Greater Goal: Be The Goat |url=http://www.tennis.com/pro-game/2017/04/cori-gauff-13-has-great-potential-and-greater-goal-be-goat/65662/ |first=Ed |last=McGrogan|date=March 21, 2019| url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181211142038/http://www.tennis.com/pro-game/2017/04/cori-gauff-13-has-great-potential-and-greater-goal-be-goat/65662/ |archive-date=December 11, 2018 |access-date=September 24, 2017 |website=Tennis.com}}</ref> She worked with Gerard Loglo at the New Generation Tennis Academy starting from the age of eight.<ref name="gauff-hopes" /><ref name="black">{{cite web |last1=Kane |first1=Portia |title=Interview with Coach Corey Gauff |url=https://blacktennismagazine.com/interview-with-coach-corey-gauff/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190701203832/https://blacktennismagazine.com/interview-with-coach-corey-gauff/ |archive-date=July 1, 2019 |access-date=7 July 2019 |website=Black Tennis Magazine}}</ref>

Gauff recalled, "I wasn't much of a team person. I loved tennis. I was so-so about it in the beginning because when I was younger I didn't want to practice at all. I just wanted to play with my friends. When I turned eight, that was when I played 'Little Mo' and after that I decided to do that for the rest of my life."<ref name="gauff-hopes">{{cite web |title=Why 12-year-old Cori Gauff hopes she'll be the greatest of all time |url=http://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/18401434/tennis-why-12-year-old-cori-gauff-thinks-greatest-all |first=Greg|last=Garber|publisher=ESPN |date=January 3, 2017 |access-date=September 11, 2017 |archive-date=July 2, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190702184022/https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/18401434/tennis-why-12-year-old-cori-gauff-thinks-greatest-all |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="us-open-2017">{{cite web |last1=Marshall |first1=Ashley |title=American teen Gauff impresses in junior Slam debut |url=https://www.usopen.org/en_US/news/articles/2017-09-05/american_teen_gauff_impresses_in_junior_slam_debut.html |website=US Open |date=September 5, 2017|access-date=September 10, 2023 |archive-date=August 23, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230823005141/https://www.usopen.org/en_US/news/articles/2017-09-05/american_teen_gauff_impresses_in_junior_slam_debut.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

Gauff's parents gave up their careers to focus on training their daughter. Her father later became her primary coach, while her mother oversaw her [[homeschooling]]. Her father had limited experience playing tennis growing up.<ref name="undefeated" /><ref name="gauff-hopes" /> At the age of 10, Gauff began to train at the [[Mouratoglou Tennis Academy]] in France run by [[Patrick Mouratoglou]], longtime coach of [[Serena Williams]]. Mouratoglou commented, "I'll always remember the first time I saw Coco. She came over to the Mouratoglou Academy in 2014 to try out and she impressed me with her determination, athleticism and fighting spirit.... When she looks at you and tells you she will be number one, you can only believe it."<ref name="upi">{{cite web |last1=Butler |first1=Alex |title=Cori Gauff, 15, makes historic Wimbledon debut |url=https://www.upi.com/Sports_News/2019/07/01/Cori-Gauff-15-makes-historic-Wimbledon-debut/5161561731627/ |website=UPI |date=July 1, 2019|access-date=7 July 2019 |archive-date=July 7, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190707023846/https://www.upi.com/Sports_News/2019/07/01/Cori-Gauff-15-makes-historic-Wimbledon-debut/5161561731627/ |url-status=live }}</ref> He helped sponsor Gauff through his Champ'Seed foundation, which he created to provide funding for talented juniors who did not have the financial resources to afford high-level training.<ref>{{cite web |title=Cori Gauff, the Revelation of Champ'Seed |url=http://www.champseedfoundation.com/en/latest-news/2017-09-18-cori-gauff-the-revelation-of-champseed/ |website=Champ'Seed Foundation |date=September 18, 2017|access-date=7 July 2019 |archive-date=July 1, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190701203833/http://www.champseedfoundation.com/en/latest-news/2017-09-18-cori-gauff-the-revelation-of-champseed/ |url-status=dead }}</ref>

Gauff won the USTA Clay Court National 12-and-under title at the age of 10 years and three months to become the youngest champion in the tournament's history.<ref name="gauff-hopes" />

==Junior career==
=== French Open singles and US Open doubles champion===
Gauff is a former world No. 1 junior.<ref name="itf-junior-profile">{{cite web |title=Cori Gauff |url=https://www.itftennis.com/juniors/players/player/profile.aspx?playerid=100320577 |website=ITF World Tennis Tour |access-date=6 July 2019 |archive-date=July 3, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190703173419/https://www.itftennis.com/juniors/players/player/profile.aspx?playerid=100320577 |url-status=dead }}</ref> She entered the prestigious [[Les Petits As]] 14-and-under tournament in 2016 at age 12 and made it to the semifinals.<ref>{{cite web |title=Andreescu to Gauff: Ngounoue joins rich tradition at Les Petits As|first=
Matt |last=Fitzgerald|date= October 13, 2019 |url=https://www.tennis.com/pro-game/2019/10/les-petits-le-mondial-lacoste-gauff-nadal-andreescu-ngounoue-wta-future-stars/85447/ |website=Tennis.com |access-date=26 October 2019 |archive-date=October 13, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191013140858/https://www.tennis.com/pro-game/2019/10/les-petits-le-mondial-lacoste-gauff-nadal-andreescu-ngounoue-wta-future-stars/85447/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Gauff began playing on the [[ITF Junior Circuit]] at the age of 13, skipping directly to the highest-level Grade A and Grade 1 tournaments. She finished runner-up to [[Jaimee Fourlis]] in her third career event, the Grade 1 Prince George's County Junior Tennis Championships in Maryland.<ref>{{cite web |title=Fourlis Sweeps Girls Titles, Mejia Wins Both Boys Championships at ITF Grade 1 Prince George's County International Hard Courts |url=http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2017/08/fourlis-sweeps-girls-titles-mejia-wins.html |last1=Lewis |first1=Colette |website=ZooTennis.com |date=August 26, 2017 |access-date=6 July 2019 |archive-date=July 6, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190706093255/http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2017/08/fourlis-sweeps-girls-titles-mejia-wins.html |url-status=live }}</ref> At her next event, Gauff made her junior [[Grand Slam (tennis)|Grand Slam]] debut at the [[2017 US Open (tennis)|2017 US Open]] and finished runner-up to [[Amanda Anisimova]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Lewis |first1=Colette |title=Anisimova Downs Gauff for US Open Girls Championship; Wu Makes History with Boys Title; Danilovic and Kostyuk Claim Girls Doubles Crown |url=http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2017/09/anisimova-downs-gauff-for-us-open-girls.html |website=ZooTennis.com|date=September 10, 2017 |access-date=6 July 2019 |archive-date=July 6, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190706093256/http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2017/09/anisimova-downs-gauff-for-us-open-girls.html |url-status=live }}</ref> Gauff did not drop a set before the final in either tournament. She became the youngest girls' singles finalist in US Open history.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Lewis |first1=Colette |title=Americans Gauff and Anisimova Meet for US Open Girls Title; Geller and Wu to Decide Boys Championship; Wu and Hsu Claim Boys Doubles Crown; Stephens Beats Keys for Women's Title |url=http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2017/09/americans-gauff-and-anisimova-meet-for.html |website=ZooTennis.com |date=September 9, 2017 |access-date=6 July 2019 |archive-date=July 6, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190706093254/http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2017/09/americans-gauff-and-anisimova-meet-for.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

After beginning 2018 with a semifinal at the Grade 1 Traralgon Junior International in Australia, Gauff lost her opening round match at the [[2018 Australian Open|Australian Open]].<ref name="itf-junior-profile" /> She did not enter another tournament in singles until the French, where she won her first career junior Grand Slam tournament title at the [[2018 French Open – Girls' singles|2018 French Open]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Gauff wins all-U.S. girls' final at French Open |url=https://www.usta.com/en/home/stay-current/national/gauff-tops-mcnally-to-win-french-open-girls-title.html#tab=tournaments |website=USTA |access-date=9 June 2018 }}</ref> She did not drop a set until the final, where she came from behind to defeat McNally in three sets. With the title, Gauff became the fifth youngest girls' singles champion in French Open history.<ref name="junior-french-open-title">{{cite web |title=Gauff edges McNally in all-American girls' final in Paris |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/gauff-edges-mcnally-all-american-girls-final-paris |website=WTA Tennis |date=June 9, 2018 |access-date=6 July 2019 |archive-date=July 1, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190701230352/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/gauff-edges-mcnally-all-american-girls-final-paris |url-status=live }}</ref> A month later, following another final win against McNally at the Grade 1 Junior International Roehampton, she became the No. 1 junior in the world.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Lewis |first1=Colette |title=June Aces; Gauff, Nakashima Win Grade 1 Roehampton Titles; Nanda, Mayo and Stearns Qualify for Wimbledon Junior Championships; McDonald and Isner into Wimbledon's Second Week |url=http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2018/07/june-aces-gauff-nakashima-win-grade-1.html |website=ZooTennis.com |date=July 6, 2018 |access-date=6 July 2019 |archive-date=July 7, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190707001106/http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2018/07/june-aces-gauff-nakashima-win-grade-1.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Lewis |first1=Colette |title=Kodat, Vallabhaneni, Bicknell and Wiersholm Win ITF Junior Circuit Titles; Gauff Moves to Top Spot in ITF Junior Rankings; Altamirano, Pegula Take Early Lead in US Open Wild Card Race; Liu, Aragone Qualify for WTA and ATP Events |url=http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2018/07/kodat-vallabhaneni-bicknell-and.html |website=ZooTennis.com |date=July 16, 2018 |access-date=6 July 2019 |archive-date=July 7, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190707001103/http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2018/07/kodat-vallabhaneni-bicknell-and.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

Gauff reached the quarterfinals in singles at the final two Grand Slam tournaments of the year. She fared better in doubles at both tournaments, reaching the semifinals at [[2018 Wimbledon|Wimbledon]] with partner [[María Lourdes Carlé]] and winning her first junior Grand Slam doubles title at the [[2018 US Open – Girls' doubles|2018 US Open]] with McNally.<ref name="itf-junior-profile" /> Gauff and McNally defeated compatriots [[Hailey Baptiste]] and [[Dalayna Hewitt]] in the final, all in straight sets.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Lewis |first1=Colette |title=Seyboth Wild and Wang Make History at US Open Junior Championships; McNally and Gauff Capture Girls Doubles Title |url=http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2018/09/seyboth-wild-and-wang-makes-history-at.html |website=ZooTennis.com |date=September 9, 2018 |access-date=7 July 2019 |archive-date=July 7, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190707001105/http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2018/09/seyboth-wild-and-wang-makes-history-at.html |url-status=live }}</ref> In September 2018, Gauff represented the United States at the [[Junior Davis Cup and Junior Fed Cup|Junior Fed Cup]] with [[Alexa Noel]] and Connie Ma. The team reached the final against Ukraine. After Gauff won her singles rubber and Noel lost hers, Gauff and Noel won the Junior Fed Cup by defeating Lyubov Kostenko and Dasha Lopatetskaya 11–9 in a match tiebreak.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Lewis |first1=Colette |title=US Girls Win Second Straight Junior Fed Cup Title, Spain Claims Junior Davis Cup; Muhammad and Mmoh Capture Titles in Templeton and Tiburon |url=http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2018/09/us-girls-win-second-straight-junior-fed.html |website=ZooTennis.com |date=September 30, 2018 |access-date=6 July 2019 |archive-date=July 7, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190707001105/http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2018/09/us-girls-win-second-straight-junior-fed.html |url-status=live }}</ref> Gauff finished the year with another Grade A title in singles at the [[Orange Bowl (tennis)|Orange Bowl]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Lewis |first1=Colette |title=Gauff Comeback Ends with Another Orange Bowl Title; Finland's Virtanen Makes History with Victory over Khan |url=http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2018/12/gauff-comeback-ends-with-another-orange.html |website=ZooTennis.com |date=December 9, 2018 |access-date=6 July 2019 |archive-date=July 7, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190707001107/http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2018/12/gauff-comeback-ends-with-another-orange.html |url-status=live }}</ref> She ended the season ranked world No. 2 behind [[Clara Burel]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Lewis |first1=Colette |title=Burel and Tseng Named 2018 ITF World Junior Champions; Cressy Wins Tallahassee Futures; Racquet Club of Memphis, Site of USTA Girls Clay Courts, to Close |url=http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2018/12/burel-and-tseng-named-2018-itf-world.html |website=ZooTennis.com |date=December 10, 2018 |access-date=6 July 2019 |archive-date=July 7, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190707001104/http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2018/12/burel-and-tseng-named-2018-itf-world.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

==Professional career==
===2018–19: First titles, top 100===
Gauff made her debut on the [[ITF Women's Circuit]] in May 2018 at the age of 14 as a qualifier in the $25k event at [[Osprey, Florida|Osprey]], where she won her first professional match.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/Rising_Stars/55351/14yearold-cori-gauff-sets-another-milestone-in-her-goat-quest/|title=14-year-old Cori Gauff sets another milestone in her GOAT quest!|website=Tennis World USA|date=May 24, 2018|access-date=12 July 2019|archive-date=July 12, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190712092627/https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/Rising_Stars/55351/14yearold-cori-gauff-sets-another-milestone-in-her-goat-quest/|url-status=live}}</ref> She received a wild card into qualifying at the [[2018 US Open (tennis)|US Open]], but lost her opening match five months after turning 14 years old.<ref name="itf-profile">{{cite web |title=Cori Gauff |url=https://www.itftennis.com/procircuit/players/player/profile.aspx?playerid=100320577 |website=ITF World Tennis Tour |access-date=6 July 2019 |archive-date=July 26, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180726201734/https://www.itftennis.com/procircuit/players/player/profile.aspx?playerid=100320577 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://baseline.tennis.com/article/76223/americans-struggle-day-2-qualifies-us-open|title=Americans struggle on Day 2 of US Open qualifying|website=Baseline|date=August 23, 2018|access-date=July 12, 2019|archive-date=July 12, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190712092631/http://baseline.tennis.com/article/76223/americans-struggle-day-2-qualifies-us-open|url-status=live}}</ref> In her first 2019 tournament, she finished runner-up in doubles at the $100k [[2019 Dow Tennis Classic|Midland Tennis Classic]] alongside [[Ann Li (tennis)|Ann Li]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Lewis |first1=Colette |title=McNally Upsets Top Seed Peterson to Reach Midland $100K Final; Cressy Advances to Cleveland Challenger Final; Forbes Wins Grade 1 in Ecuador |url=http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2019/02/mcnally-upsets-top-seed-peterson-to.html |website=ZooTennis.com |date=February 2, 2019 |access-date=6 July 2019 |archive-date=July 6, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190706234755/http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2019/02/mcnally-upsets-top-seed-peterson-to.html |url-status=live }}</ref> Two weeks later, Gauff played her next event at the $25k level in [[Surprise, Arizona|Surprise]] and reached the finals in both singles and doubles. She finished runner-up in singles and won her first WTA Tour title in doubles alongside [[Paige Hourigan]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Lewis |first1=Colette |title=Wake Forest, Ohio State Advance to Men's D-I ITA Team Indoor Final; Redlicki Wins Tucson Title, Gauff Comes Up Short in Surprise; Opelka Captures New York Open |url=http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2019/02/wake-forest-ohio-state-advance-to-mens.html |website=ZooTennis.com |date=February 17, 2019 |access-date=6 July 2019 |archive-date=July 6, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190706234757/http://tenniskalamazoo.blogspot.com/2019/02/wake-forest-ohio-state-advance-to-mens.html |url-status=live }}</ref> In March, at the [[2019 Miami Open|Miami Open]], she recorded her first WTA Tour match win against [[Caty McNally]].<ref>{{cite web | title=2019 Miami Open: Gauff 'controls the controllables,' marvels in first WTA win | url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2019-miami-open-gauff-controls-controllables-marvels-first-wta-win | website=WTA Tennis | date=21 March 2019 | access-date=2 July 2019 | archive-date=July 1, 2019 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190701230339/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2019-miami-open-gauff-controls-controllables-marvels-first-wta-win | url-status=live }}</ref>

Gauff lost the second round of qualifying at the [[2019 French Open|French Open]]. At [[2019 Wimbledon Championships|Wimbledon]], she defeated [[Aliona Bolsova]] and [[Greet Minnen]]. Gauff became the youngest player to reach the main draw at Wimbledon by qualifying in the Open Era at the age of 15 years and three months.<ref>{{cite web |title=American Cori 'Coco' Gauff becomes youngest Wimbledon qualifier in Open Era history |url=https://www.smh.com.au/sport/american-cori-coco-gauff-becomes-youngest-wimbledon-qualifier-in-open-era-history-20190628-p522c9.html |website=Sydney Morning Herald |date=June 28, 2019 |access-date=July 6, 2019 |archive-date=July 6, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190706234256/https://www.smh.com.au/sport/american-cori-coco-gauff-becomes-youngest-wimbledon-qualifier-in-open-era-history-20190628-p522c9.html |url-status=live }}</ref> In her main-draw debut, she upset five-time Wimbledon champion [[Venus Williams]] in straight sets.<ref name="nyt-venus">{{cite news |last1=Clarey |first1=Christopher |title=Cori Gauff, 15, Seizes Her Moment, Upsetting Venus Williams at Wimbledon |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/01/sports/cori-gauff-venus-williams-wimbledon.html |newspaper=The New York Times |date=July 2019 |access-date=July 6, 2019 |archive-date=July 6, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190706054106/https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/01/sports/cori-gauff-venus-williams-wimbledon.html |url-status=live }}</ref> Gauff won over [[Magdaléna Rybáriková]] and No. 60 [[Polona Hercog]], saving two match points against Hercog. The hype surrounding Gauff's first-round match win led to her third rounder moving to [[Centre Court]].<ref name="wimbledon-second-round">{{cite web |last1=Tignor |first1=Steve |title=Coco Gauff is the youngest at Wimbledon, but she plays a grown-up game |url=http://www.tennis.com/pro-game/2019/07/cori-coco-gauff-magdalena-rybarikova-wimbledon-second-round-2019/83118/ |website=Tennis.com |date=July 3, 2019 |access-date=6 July 2019 |archive-date=July 6, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190706013120/http://www.tennis.com/pro-game/2019/07/cori-coco-gauff-magdalena-rybarikova-wimbledon-second-round-2019/83118/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title='It's pretty surreal how life changes': Gauff halts Hercog, sets Halep battle at Wimbledon |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/1447008/it-s-pretty-surreal-how-life-changes-gauff-halts-hercog-sets-halep-battle-at-wimbledon |website=WTA Tennis |date=July 5, 2019 |access-date=6 July 2019 |archive-date=September 8, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230908185357/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/1447008/it-s-pretty-surreal-how-life-changes-gauff-halts-hercog-sets-halep-battle-at-wimbledon |url-status=live }}</ref> She was eliminated with a fourth-round loss to eventual champion [[Simona Halep]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2019/jul/08/the-coco-bubble-pops-at-wimbledon-as-simona-halep-ousts-cori-gauff|title=The Coco bubble pops at Wimbledon as Simona Halep ousts Cori four of Gauff's matches were most-watched matches on [[ESPN]] on their respective days during the first week of coverage.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Nagle |first1=Dave |title=Wimbledon Viewership up 29%; Coco, Sport's Legends Provide Compelling Action |url=https://espnpressroom.com/us/press-releases/2019/07/wimbledon-viewership-up-29-coco-sports-legends-provide-compelling-action/ |website=ESPN Press }}</ref> With this performance, she rose to world No. 141.<ref>{{cite web | title=WTA rankings Update 2019: Halep returns to Top 5, Gauff soars | url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/wta-rankings-update-2019-halep-returns-top-5-gauff-soars |first=Alex |last=Macpherson| work=WTA Tennis | date=July 15, 2019 | access-date=July 16, 2019 | Gauff played in one [[US Open Series]] tournament at the [[2019 Citi Open|Washington Open]], where she qualified for the main draw but lost in the first round.<ref>{{cite web | title=Gauff cruises into Citi Open main draw | url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/gauff-cruises-citi-open-main-draw | website=WTA Tennis | date=July 28, 2019 | access-date=July 30, 2019 | archive-date=July 30, 2019 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190730053207/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/gauff-cruises-citi-open-main-draw | url-status=live }}</ref> She entered the doubles event with McNally and defeated [[Fanny Stollár]] and [[Maria Sanchez (tennis)|Maria Sanchez]] in the final for their first career WTA title in their first joint WTA.<ref>{{cite news |title=Gauff, McNally win Citi Open doubles: 'The way we're playing, we can go as far as we want' |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/gauff-mcnally-win-citi-open-doubles-way-were-playing-we-can-go-far-we-want |access-date=August 4, 2019 |website=WTA Tennis |date=August 3, 2019 |archive-date=August 4, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190804101433/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/gauff-mcnally-win-citi-open-doubles-way-were-playing-we-can-go-far-we-want |url-status=live }}</ref> At the [[2019 US Open – Women's singles|US Open]], Gauff wild-carded into the singles and doubles main draws. She continued her Grand Slam success in singles with two three-set wins over [[Anastasia Potapova]] and [[Tímea Babos]], both on [[Louis Armstrong Stadium|Louis Armstrong]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Clarey |first1=Christopher |title=Coco Gauff Delivers Again, in an Electric U.S. Open Win |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/27/sports/coco-gauff-us-open.html?action=click&module=Well&pgtype=Homepage&section=Sports |newspaper=The New York Times |date=August 28, 2019 |access-date=August 28, 2019 |archive-date=August 17, 2020 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Tignor |first1=Steve |title=In A Tenacious Tug of War, Coco Gauff Brings Armstrong House Down |url=http://www.tennis.com/pro-game/2019/08/coco-cori-gauff-timea-babos-second-round-2019-us-open/84655/ |website=Tennis.com |date=August 30, 2019 |access-date=August 29, 2019 |archive-date=August 30, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190830044948/http://www.tennis.com/pro-game/2019/08/coco-cori-gauff-timea-babos-second-round-2019-us-open/84655/ |url-status=live }}</ref> She was defeated in the third round by world No. 1 and defending champion [[Naomi Osaka]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Livaudais |first1=Stephanie |title='Coco, I think you're amazing' – Naomi Osaka and Coco Gauff's emotional moment after US Open clash |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/1445684/-coco-i-think-you-re-amazing-naomi-osaka-and-coco-gauff-s-emotional-moment-after-us-open-clash |url-status=live }}</ref> In doubles, Gauff and McNally won two matches, including an upset over ninth seeds [[Nicole Melichar]] and [[Květa Peschke]].<ref name=nyt-mccoco>{{cite news |last1=Streeter |first1=Kurt |title=Team 'McCoco' Takes a Turn in the Spotlight |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/01/sports/tennis/us-open-coco-gauff-caty-mcnally.html |access-date=October 23, 2019 |newspaper=The |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190916121117/https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/01/sports/tennis/us-open-coco-gauff-caty-mcnally.html |url-status=live }}</ref> They lost in the third round to eventual runners-up [[Ashleigh Barty]] and [[Victoria Azarenka]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Di Costanzo |first1=Diane |title=Victoria Azarenka and Ashleigh Barty end Gauff, McNally run |url=https://www.usopen.org/amp/en_US/news/articles/2019-09-02/victoria_azarenka_and_ashleigh_barty_end_gauff_mcnally_run.html |access-date=September 3, 2019 |work=US Open |date=September 2, 2019 [[Jeļena Ostapenko]] in the final to become the youngest WTA player, at age 15, to win a singles title since 2004.<ref name="first-title">{{cite web |title='It's been an unbelievable week for me' – ===2020: Australian Open fourth round===
Starting 2020 at the [[2020 ASB Classic|Auckland Open]] ranked No. 67 in the world, Gauff defeated [[Viktória Kužmová]] before losing to [[Laura Siegemund]] in the second round.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/sport/tennis/118689712/teen-star-coco-gauff-loses-to-laura-siegemund-at-asb-classic|title=Teen star Coco Gauff fights back tears after losing at ASB Classic|first=David|last=Long|date=January 9, 2020|work=[[Stuff (website)|Stuff]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210513101734/https://www.stuff.co.nz/sport/tennis/118689712/teen-star-coco-gauff-loses-to-laura-siegemund-at-asb-classic|archive-date=May 13, 2021|url-status=live|access-date=January 23, 2020}}</ref> Playing doubles with McNally, Gauff reached the semifinals.

At the [[2020 Australian Open – Women's singles|Australian Open]], Gauff defeated Venus Williams in straight sets in the first round<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/live/tennis/50254773|title=Listen: Djokovic reaches Australian Open second round|date=January 19, 2020|publisher=[[BBC News]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210510144045/https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/live/tennis/50254773|archive-date=May 10, 2021|url-status=live|access-date=January 20, 2020}}</ref> and [[Sorana Cîrstea]] in the second round, making it three straight Grand Slams where she reached the third round.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/tennis-live-updates-australian-open-tennis-day-three-at-melbourne-park/RCLWVU2D7COPNLA6GVWAUSH6EU/|title=Tennis: Live updates: Australian Open tennis, day three at Melbourne Park|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|date=January 22, 2020|access-date=March 25, 2021|archive-date=May 10, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210510143829/https://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/tennis-live-updates-australian-open-tennis-day-three-at-melbourne-park/RCLWVU2D7COPNLA6GVWAUSH6EU/|url-status=live}}</ref> She defeated defending champion Osaka<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/staggering-awkwardness-in-naomi-osakas-australian-open-implosion/AOVPLP7IL6JWMCT3DN2WX4XCII/|title=Staggering awkwardness in Naomi Osaka's Australian Open 'implosion'|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210510143829/https://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/tennis-live-updates-australian-open-tennis-day-three-at-melbourne-park/RCLWVU2D7COPNLA6GVWAUSH6EU/|archive-date=May 10, 2021|url-status=live|access-date=March 25, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Tennis: Coco Gauff sets up showdown with Naomi Osaka at Australian Open |url=https://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/news/article.cfm?c_id=4&objectid=12302673 |access-date=19 July 2021 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |date=23 January 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200128214410/https://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/news/article.cfm?c_id=4&objectid=12302673 |archive-date=January 28, 2020 |url-status=dead }}</ref> in the third, becoming the youngest player to defeat a top-5 player since [[Jennifer Capriati]] beat [[Gabriela Sabatini]] at the [[1991 US Open – Women's singles|1991 US Open]]. In the fourth round, she lost to the eventual champion, [[Sofia Kenin]]. In doubles, Gauff and McNally recorded their best result in a Grand Slam championship to date, reaching the quarterfinals before falling to second seeds and eventual champions, [[Kristina Mladenovic]] and Tímea Babos.<ref name="2020 Australian Open Doubles">{{Cite news |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/1590901/babos-mladenovic-prove-too-good-for-gauff-mcnally-in-melbourne-doubles |title=Babos, Mladenovic prove too good for Gauff, McNally in Melbourne doubles |work=WTA Tennis |date=January 28, 2020 |access-date=January 28, 2020 |archive-date=November 4, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221104171632/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/1590901/babos-mladenovic-prove-too-good-for-gauff-mcnally-in-melbourne-doubles |url-status=live }}</ref>

Gauff beat two top-50 players at the [[Top Seed Open|Lexington Challenger]], before losing in straight sets to world No. 49, [[Jennifer Brady]]. At the Western and Southern Open, played in New York, Gauff lost in the first round to world No. 21, [[Maria Sakkari]]. At the [[2020 US Open – Women's singles|US Open]], Gauff was defeated in the first round by [[Anastasija Sevastova]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.eurosport.com/tennis/us-open/2020/rising-star-cori-gauff-loses-in-first-round-at-us-open-i-ve-still-got-a-lot-to-learn_sto7860265/story.shtml |title=Cori Gauff loses in first round at US Open – 'I've still got a lot to learn' |work=eurosport.com |date=September 1, 2020 |access-date=1 September 2020 |archive-date=September 9, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230909230324/https://www.eurosport.com/geoblocking.shtml |url-status=live }}</ref>

Gauff, ranked 53, beat world No. 34, [[Ons Jabeur]], in the first round of the [[Italian Open (tennis)|Italian Open]] before losing to two-time Grand Slam champion [[Garbiñe Muguruza]]. At the [[2020 French Open – Women's singles|French Open]], Gauff defeated the ninth seed and world No. 13, [[Johanna Konta]], in the first round, but went on to lose to eventual quarterfinalist [[Martina Trevisan]] in a second-round match in which Gauff hit 19 double faults. At the [[Ostrava Open]], she  qualified for the main draw and was defeated by world No. 12, [[Aryna Sabalenka]], in the second round.

===2021: French Open quarterfinals, top 20===
[[File:Gauff RG21 (6) (51375375152).jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.9|Gauff at the [[2021 French Open]]]]
Starting the year ranked No. 48, in the [[Abu Dhabi Open]], she beat Norwegian [[Ulrikke Eikeri]] before falling in the next round to Maria Sakkari.<ref name="auto2">{{Cite news |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/players/328560/cori-gauff/matches |title=Cori Gauff – Matches |work=wta.com |access-date=22 March 2021 |archive-date=April 11, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210411090740/https://www.wtatennis.com/players/328560/cori-gauff/matches |url-status=live }}</ref> At the [[2021 Australian Open – Women's singles|Australian Open]], in singles, Gauff again beat Teichmann in the first round, but fell in the round of 64 to the fifth-seeded [[Elina Svitolina]], in straight sets.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.eurosport.com/tennis/australian-open/2021/australian-open-2021-coco-gauff-s-game-too-big-and-so-is-the-expectation-around-her_sto8117322/story.shtml |title=Coco Gauff's Game Too Big–And So is the Expectation Around Her |work=eurosport.com |first=Carrie |last=Dunn |date=February 11, 2021 |access-date=22 March 2021 |archive-date=September 9, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230909230326/https://www.eurosport.com/geoblocking.shtml |url-status=live }}</ref> In doubles, she and McNally failed to Demi Schuurs and Nicole Melichar in the quarterfinals.<ref name="auto2"/>

At Adelaide, she failed to second seeded [[Belinda Bencic]].<ref name="auto1">{{Cite news |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/players/328560/cori-gauff/matches |title=Cori Gauff – Matches |work=wta.com |access-date=23 March 2021 |archive-date=April 11, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210411090740/https://www.wtatennis.com/players/328560/cori-gauff/matches |url-status=live }}</ref> In doubles, she partnered with Canadian [[Sharon Fichman]], and they bowed out in the first round to [[Duan Yingying]] and [[Zheng Saisai]].<ref name="auto1"/> This run brought her to a then-career-high of No. 38 in singles.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/rankings/singles |title=Singles Rankings – 03/01/2021 |work=wta.com |access-date=23 March 2021 |archive-date=April 24, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170424135418/http://www.wtatennis.com/singles-rankings |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/rankings/doubles |title=Doubles Rankings – 03/01/2021 |work=wta.com |access-date=23 March 2021 |archive-date=March 14, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210314002235/https://www.wtatennis.com/rankings/doubles |url-status=live }}</ref> After the [[Dubai Tennis Championships|Dubai Championships]], she reaches a career high of No. 35 in singles.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/rankings/singles |title=Singles Rankings – 03/15/2021 |work=wta.com |access-date=23 March 2021 |archive-date=April 24, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170424135418/http://www.wtatennis.com/singles-rankings |url-status=live }}</ref>

In the [[2021 Miami Open|Miami Open]], she played her first WTA 1000 event while seeded (as the 31st). In May, Gauff reached the first semifinal at a WTA 1000 in her career at the [[2021 Italian Open (tennis)|Italian Open]] due to then-No. 1, Barty, retiring with a right arm injury in their quarterfinal match.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2142284/gauff-through-to-rome-semifinals-as-barty-retires|title=Gauff through to Rome semifinals as Barty retires|publisher=Women's Tennis Association|date=May 14, 2021|access-date=May 14, 2021|archive-date=May 14, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210514172145/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2142284/gauff-through-to-rome-semifinals-as-barty-retires|url-status=live}}</ref> As a result, she entered top 30 for the first time. She then lost to the eventual champion, [[Iga Świątek]].

Gauff won her second singles and third doubles (with McNally) titles at the [[2021 Emilia-Romagna Open|Emilia-Romagna Open]] in Parma. She became the youngest player to win both the singles and doubles titles at an event since [[Maria Sharapova]] won both titles at the [[2004 DFS Classic|2004 Birmingham Classic]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2153537/gauff-sweeps-singles-and-doubles-titles-in-parma|title=Gauff sweeps singles and doubles titles in Parma|publisher=Women's Tennis Association|date=May 22, 2021|access-date=May 22, 2021|archive-date=May 22, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210522192604/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2153537/gauff-sweeps-singles-and-doubles-titles-in-parma|url-status=live}}</ref> Gauff thus rose to new career-high rankings of world No. 25 in singles and No. 41 in doubles. She became the youngest American to make her top 25 debut in nearly 23 years (since Serena Williams, June 8, 1998).<ref>{{cite web |title=WTA Rankings Watch: Gauff, Badosa reach career highs |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2159780/wta-rankings-watch-gauff-badosa-reach-career-highs |publisher=[[Women's Tennis Association]] |access-date=19 July 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210524151003/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2159780/wta-rankings-watch-gauff-badosa-reach-career-highs |archive-date=May 24, 2021 |url-status=live }}</ref>

Seeded 24th at the [[2021 French Open – Women's singles|French Open]] (her first time being seeded at a Grand Slam), she beat [[Aleksandra Krunić]] and [[Wang Qiang (tennis)|Wang Qiang]] in straight sets, received a walkover when leading one set to love against 13th seed and Australian Open runner-up [[Jennifer Brady]], and beat 25th seed [[Ons Jabeur]] in just 53 minutes to reach her first Grand Slam quarterfinal. As a result, she became the youngest female player (17 years, three months) to reach a Grand Slam quarterfinal since [[Nicole Vaidišová]] at the 2006 French Open, the youngest American to reach a quarterfinal at Roland Garros since [[Jennifer Capriati]] in 1993 and the youngest American to reach the quarterfinals of any Grand Slam since [[Venus Williams]] reached the 1997 US Open final.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2167316/gauff-sakkari-clinch-first-slam-quarterfinal-showings-at-french-open|title=Gauff, Sakkari clinch first Slam quarterfinal showings at French Open|publisher=Women's Tennis Association|date=June 7, 2021|access-date=June 7, 2021|archive-date=June 7, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210607181605/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2167316/gauff-sakkari-clinch-first-slam-quarterfinal-showings-at-french-open|url-status=live}}</ref> Subsequently, Gauff was eliminated after losing in straight sets to the eventual champion, unseeded [[Barbora Krejčíková]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Kerber wins generation game to knock Gauff out at Wimbledon |url=https://www.news24.com/sport/Tennis/FrenchOpen/unseeded-krejcikova-reaches-first-grand-slam-semi-final-at-french-open-20210609 |access-date=July 5, 2021 |website=reuters.com |date=July 5, 2021 |archive-date=June 25, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210625130722/https://www.news24.com/sport/tennis/frenchopen/unseeded-krejcikova-reaches-first-grand-slam-semi-final-at-french-open-20210609 |url-status=live }}</ref> As a result, she reached a new career-high of No. 23.

At [[2021 Wimbledon Championships – Women's singles|Wimbledon]], Gauff reached the fourth round for a second consecutive time defeating [[Elena Vesnina]] in straight sets in 70 minutes,<ref>{{cite news |last1=Maine |first1=D'Arcy |title=Two years after bursting onto the scene at Wimbledon, 17-year-old Coco Gauff advances to third round |url=https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/31744642/two-years-bursting-scene-wimbledon-17-year-old-coco-gauff-advances-third-round |access-date=19 July 2021 |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=1 July 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210711140713/https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/31744642/two-years-bursting-scene-wimbledon-17-year-old-coco-gauff-advances-third-round |archive-date=July 11, 2021 |url-status=live }}</ref> and [[Kaja Juvan]] in straight sets in the third round.<ref>{{cite news |title=Coco Gauff matches 2019 breakout by reaching 4th round at Wimbledon again |url=https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/31755475/coco-gauff-matches-2019-breakout-reaching-4th-round-wimbledon-again |access-date=19 July 2021 |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=3 July 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210711184645/https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/31755475/coco-gauff-matches-2019-breakout-reaching-4th-round-wimbledon-again |archive-date=July 11, 2021 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Kane |first1=David |title=Fast and furious: Coco Gauff's exponential improvements on display through a stunning first week at Wimbledon |url=https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/coco-gauff-american-usa-teenager-wimbledon-venus-results |publisher=Tennis.com |access-date=19 July 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210704000115/https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/coco-gauff-american-usa-teenager-wimbledon-venus-results |archive-date=July 4, 2021 |date=3 July 2021 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Gauff lost her next match to [[Angelique Kerber]] in straight sets, eliminating her from the tournament.<ref>{{cite news |title=Kerber wins generation game to knock Gauff out at Wimbledon |url=https://www.reuters.com/lifestyle/sports/kerber-wins-generation-game-knock-gauff-out-wimbledon-2021-07-05/ |access-date=June 9, 2021 |work=[[Reuters]] |date=June 9, 2021 |archive-date=July 5, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210705170332/https://www.reuters.com/lifestyle/sports/kerber-wins-generation-game-knock-gauff-out-wimbledon-2021-07-05/ |url-status=live }}</ref> She also reached the third round in doubles with Caty McNally and as a result entered the top 40 in the doubles rankings at No. 38 on 12 July.

At 17 years old, she was selected for the [[Tennis at the 2020 Summer Olympics|2020 Summer Olympics]] in Tokyo, becoming the second youngest American player after Jennifer Capriati competed at 16 in 1992 and the youngest Olympic tennis player of any gender since [[Mario Ančić]] in 2000.<ref>{{cite news |title=U.S. Olympic tennis team named, including Coco Gauff |url=https://olympics.nbcsports.com/2021/07/01/usa-olympic-tennis-team-roster-coco-gauff/ |access-date=19 July 2021 |work=[[NBC Sports]] |date=1 July 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210718193251/https://olympics.nbcsports.com/2021/07/01/usa-olympic-tennis-team-roster-coco-gauff/ |archive-date=July 18, 2021 |url-status=live }}</ref> However, she tested positive for COVID-19 and was forced to withdraw.<ref>{{cite web |last1=McGrogan |first1=Ed |title=Coco Gauff, Roger Federer, Matteo Berretini and more withdraw from Tokyo Olympic Games |url=https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/coco-gauff-roger-federer-matteo-berrettini-and-more-withdraw-from-tokyo-olympic-/ |publisher=Tennis.com |access-date=19 July 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210718194119/https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/coco-gauff-roger-federer-matteo-berrettini-and-more-withdraw-from-tokyo-olympic- |archive-date=July 18, 2021 |date=13 July 2021 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

At the [[2021 Western & Southern Open|Cincinnati Open]], Gauff reached the second round and lost to second seed, and world No. 2, [[Naomi Osaka]].
 
At the [[2021 US Open – Women's singles|US Open]], Gauff beat [[Magda Linette]] in the first round, before falling to [[Sloane Stephens]] in the next. In the women's doubles, Gauff and McNally stormed into their first Grand Slam semifinal without dropping a set and in the finals, they lost to [[Samantha Stosur|Sam Stosur]] and [[Zhang Shuai]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Sam Stosur-Zhang Shuai top Coco Gauff-Caty McNally in US Open women's doubles final |url=https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/32197570/sam-stosur-zhang-shuai-top-coco-gauff-caty-mcnally-doubles-final |publisher=ESPN |date=September 12, 2021 |access-date=January 17, 2022 |archive-date=September 30, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220930201000/https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/32197570/sam-stosur-zhang-shuai-top-coco-gauff-caty-mcnally-doubles-final |url-status=live }}</ref>

===2022: French Open final, top 5, doubles No. 1===
Seeded 18th at the [[2022 Australian Open – Women's singles|Australian Open]], Gauff lost in the first round against Wang Qiang in straight sets.<ref>{{cite news |title=Australian Open 2022 – Coco Gauff Hits 38 Unforced Errors as She's Stunned by Wang Qiang in Straight Sets |url=https://www.eurosport.com/tennis/australian-open/2022/australian-open-2022-coco-gauff-hits-38-unforced-errors-as-she-s-stunned-by-wang-qiang-in-straight-s_sto8716244/story.shtml |work=Eurosport |date=January 17, 2021 |access-date=January 17, 2022 |archive-date=September 9, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230909230326/https://www.eurosport.com/geoblocking.shtml |url-status=live }}</ref>

In February, Gauff reached the quarterfinals at the [[2022 Qatar Total Open – Singles|Qatar Open]] by defeating [[Shelby Rogers]], Caroline Garcia and third seed [[Paula Badosa]]. In the quarterfinals, Gauff lost to sixth seed Maria Sakkari. In [[2022 Qatar Total Open – Doubles|doubles]], Gauff paired with [[Jessica Pegula]] to win her first WTA 1000 doubles title, beating third-seeded pair of [[Veronika Kudermetova]] and [[Elise Mertens]] in the final.<ref>{{cite news |title=Gauff, Pegula charge to doubles title in Doha |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2504816/gauff-pegula-charge-to-doubles-title-in-doha |work=WTA |date=February 25, 2022 |access-date=February 28, 2022 |archive-date=February 25, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220225205748/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2504816/gauff-pegula-charge-to-doubles-title-in-doha |url-status=live }}</ref> With the win, she climbed to a career-high No. 10 in the doubles rankings on February 28, 2022.

Gauff reached her first Grand Slam singles final at the [[2022 French Open|French Open]], defeating [[Rebecca Marino]], [[Alison Van Uytvanck]], Kaia Kanepi, 31st seed Elise Mertens, [[Sloane Stephens]], and Martina Trevisan, before losing to [[Iga Świątek]] in straight sets.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/34013745/coco-gauff-reaches-grand-slam-semifinals-first-beating-fellow-american-sloane-stephens-french-open-quarterfinals | title=Gauff beats Stephens, reaches first Slam semi |website=ESPN| date=May 31, 2022 | access-date=May 31, 2022 | archive-date=May 31, 2022 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220531173121/https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/34013745/coco-gauff-reaches-grand-slam-semifinals-first-beating-fellow-american-sloane-stephens-french-open-quarterfinals | url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.reuters.com/lifestyle/sports/world-number-one-swiatek-beats-gauff-win-french-open-title-2022-06-04/ | title=Ruthless Swiatek crushes Gauff to clinch 2nd French Open title | website=[[Reuters]] | date=June 4, 2022 | access-date=June 7, 2022 | archive-date=June 15, 2022 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220615111346/https://www.reuters.com/lifestyle/sports/world-number-one-swiatek-beats-gauff-win-french-open-title-2022-06-04/ | url-status=live }}</ref> She reached the final in doubles with Jessica Pegula where they were defeated by Caroline Garcia and Kristina Mladenovic.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.tennis.com/baseline/articles/doubles-take-roland-garros-draws-winding-down-womens-mens-mixed-upsets | title=Doubles Take: Roland Garros draws winding down |website=Tennis.com|first=Van |last=Sias|date=June 1, 2022| access-date=June 1, 2022 | archive-date=December 21, 2022 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221221152248/https://www.tennis.com/baseline/articles/doubles-take-roland-garros-draws-winding-down-womens-mens-mixed-upsets | url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2639187/gauff-pegula-to-meet-garcia-mladenovic-in-french-open-doubles-final | title=Gauff, Pegula to meet Garcia, Mladenovic in French Open doubles final | website=WTA | date=June 3, 2022 | access-date=June 3, 2022 | archive-date=June 3, 2022 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220603195035/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2639187/gauff-pegula-to-meet-garcia-mladenovic-in-french-open-doubles-final | url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://au.sports.yahoo.com/tennis-french-open-2022-coco-gauff-doubles-devastation-loses-two-finals-224951379.html|title=Coco Gauff suffers double devastation in French Open drama|website=Yahoo!Sport|first=Andrew|last=Reid|date=June 5, 2022|access-date=June 7, 2022|archive-date=June 7, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220607135941/https://au.sports.yahoo.com/tennis-french-open-2022-coco-gauff-doubles-devastation-loses-two-finals-224951379.html|url-status=live}}</ref> As a result, she secured a new career-high of world No. 13 in singles and the top 5 in doubles.

After winning her first two matches at [[2022 Wimbledon Championships – Women's singles|Wimbledon Championships]] as the 11th seed against unseeded Romanians [[Elena-Gabriela Ruse]] and [[Mihaela Buzărnescu]], Gauff lost in the third round to 20th [[Amanda Anisimova]] in three sets.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.eurosport.com/tennis/wimbledon/2022/wimbledon-2022-amanda-anisimova-rallies-from-a-set-down-to-stun-coco-gauff-and-reach-fourth-round_sto9015330/story.shtml|title=Wimbledon 2022: Amanda Anisimova rallies from a set down to stun Coco Gauff and reach fourth round|website=Eurosport|first=Alex|last=Livie|date=July 2, 2022|access-date=August 13, 2022|archive-date=September 9, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230909230326/https://www.eurosport.com/geoblocking.shtml|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/34189933/wimbledon-2022-coco-gauff-first-grand-slam-title-wait-how-much-longer | title=Coco Gauff's first Grand Slam title will have to wait ... But for how much longer? | website=ESPN | first=D'Arcy | last=Maine | date=July 4, 2022 | access-date=August 13, 2022 | archive-date=August 13, 2022 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220813063707/https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/34189933/wimbledon-2022-coco-gauff-first-grand-slam-title-wait-how-much-longer | url-status=live }}</ref> As a result, she reached a new career-high ranking of world No. 11, on 11 July.

Seeded sixth at the [[2022 Silicon Valley Classic|Silicon Valley Classic]], she reached the quarterfinals defeating [[Anhelina Kalinina]] in the first round, and next Naomi Osaka who saved seven match points.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2719604/three-takeaways-gauff-comes-through-wild-finish-to-beat-osaka-in-san-jose|title=Three takeaways: Gauff comes through wild finish to beat Osaka in San Jose|website=WTA|first=Courtney|last=Nguyen|date=August 5, 2022|access-date=August 5, 2022|archive-date=August 5, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220805052816/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2719604/three-takeaways-gauff-comes-through-wild-finish-to-beat-osaka-in-san-jose|url-status=live}}</ref> In her quarterfinal match, she struggled with her serve and lost in straight sets to Paula Badosa.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Tennis.com |title=Paula Badosa defeats Coco Gauff in San Jose quarterfinals; Shelby Rogers tops Amanda Anisimova |url=https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/san-jose-paula-badosa-beats-coco-gauff-rogers-anisimova-kasatkina |date=August 6, 2022 |access-date=2022-08-12 |website=Tennis.com |archive-date=August 7, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220807214501/https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/san-jose-paula-badosa-beats-coco-gauff-rogers-anisimova-kasatkina |url-status=live }}</ref>

At the [[2022 National Bank Open|Canadian Open]], she became the youngest player to reach back-to-back quarterfinals in Canada since Jennifer Capriati in 1990 and 1991. She beat sixth seed Aryna Sabalenka, a day after ousting Wimbledon champion [[Elena Rybakina]], winning both matches in a third-set tiebreak. She lost to eventual champion Simona Halep, in straight sets.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.eurosport.com/tennis/wta-montreal/2021/a-great-match-simona-halep-beats-tired-coco-gauff-in-straight-sets-to-advance-to-canadian-open-semi-_sto9082401/story.shtml | title='A great match' – Simona Halep beats tired Coco Gauff in straight sets to advance to Canadian Open semi-final | first=Sam | last=Rooke | website=Eurosport | date=August 12, 2022 | access-date=August 13, 2022 | archive-date=September 9, 2023 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230909230325/https://www.eurosport.com/geoblocking.shtml | url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2739372/by-the-numbers-halep-stays-perfect-vs-gauff-to-reach-toronto-semifinals | title=By the numbers: Halep stays perfect vs. Gauff to reach Toronto semifinals | website=WTA | date=August 12, 2022 | access-date=August 13, 2022 | archive-date=August 12, 2022 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220812224754/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2739372/by-the-numbers-halep-stays-perfect-vs-gauff-to-reach-toronto-semifinals | url-status=live }}</ref> Seeded third in doubles at the same tournament she reached the semifinals with Pegula defeating fifth seeds [[Desirae Krawczyk]] and [[Demi Schuurs]]. Next they defeated [[Madison Keys]]/[[Sania Mirza]] in the semifinals and Nicole Melichar/[[Ellen Perez]] in the final to win their second WTA 1000 title together. As a result, Gauff became the No. 1 doubles player in the world.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2744053/coco-gauff-captures-world-no-1-doubles-ranking-with-toronto-title | title=Coco Gauff captures World No.1 doubles ranking with Toronto title | website=WTA | date=August 14, 2022 | access-date=August 15, 2022 | archive-date=August 15, 2022 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220815201844/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2744053/coco-gauff-captures-world-no-1-doubles-ranking-with-toronto-title | url-status=live }}</ref>

At the [[2022 US Open (tennis)|US Open]], she reached the quarterfinals of this major for the first time with wins over 20th seed [[Madison Keys]] and [[Zhang Shuai]] becoming the youngest American woman to achieve this feat since 2009, when [[Melanie Oudin]] was 17.<ref>{{cite tweet|number=1566548895328509953|user=espn|title=Coco Gauff (18) becomes the youngest American woman to reach the US Open quarterfinals since 2009 👏 @CocoGauff |…|date=September 4, 2022}}</ref> As a result, she guaranteed herself a top 10 debut in the singles rankings at world No. 8 after the tournament.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2781533/gauff-garcia-set-for-quarterfinal-clash-at-us-open|title=Gauff, Garcia set for quarterfinal clash at US Open|website=WTA|first=Greg|last=Garber|date=September 4, 2022|access-date=September 4, 2022|archive-date=September 4, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220904232708/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/2781533/gauff-garcia-set-for-quarterfinal-clash-at-us-open|url-status=live}}</ref> Subsequently, Gauff was defeated by Caroline Garcia, in straight sets.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://inews.co.uk/sport/tennis/us-open-results-2022-coco-gauff-caroline-garcia-semi-final-draw-1837496 | title=US Open results 2022: Coco Gauff destroyed by 'fearless' Caroline Garcia to set up semi-final against Jabeur |first=James |last=Gray| website=inews.co.uk | date=6 September 2022 | access-date=September 7, 2022 | archive-date=September 7, 2022 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220907094333/https://inews.co.uk/sport/tennis/us-open-results-2022-coco-gauff-caroline-garcia-semi-final-draw-1837496 | url-status=live }}</ref> Seeded second in doubles, Gauff and partner Pegula were defeated in the first round by [[Leylah Fernandez]] and [[Daria Saville]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://tennisuptodate.com/wta/fernandez-and-saville-make-doubles-debut-dumping-out-gauff-and-pegula-at-us-open | title=Fernandez and Saville make doubles debut dumping out Gauff and Pegula at US Open | website=tennisuptodate | date=2 September 2022 | access-date=September 7, 2022 | archive-date=September 7, 2022 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220907111927/https://tennisuptodate.com/wta/fernandez-and-saville-make-doubles-debut-dumping-out-gauff-and-pegula-at-us-open | url-status=live }}</ref>

In October, Gauff became the youngest player in singles since [[Maria Sharapova]] in 2005 to qualify for the year-end [[WTA Finals]] championships. She and partner Jessica Pegula also both qualified for the doubles' championships. Gauff and Pegula were the first Americans since Serena and Venus Williams in 2009 to qualify for both the singles and doubles year-end championships.<ref>{{Cite web |date=October 20, 2022 |title=WTA Finals: Coco Gauff becomes youngest player since 2005 to qualify |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/tennis/63329154 |url-status=live |access-date=October 24, 2022 |publisher=BBC Sport |archive-date=October 24, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221024122955/https://www.bbc.com/sport/tennis/63329154 }}</ref>

===2023: US Open singles champion===
Gauff started her 2023 season at the [[WTA Auckland Open|Auckland Open]], where she defeated [[Rebeka Masarova]] in the final in straight sets. At the [[2023 Australian Open – Women's singles|Australian Open]], Gauff advanced to the fourth round, where she lost to Jeļena Ostapenko in straight sets.<ref>{{Cite web |author=Dzevad Mesic |title='Dejected' Cori Gauff after surprise AO loss to Jelena Ostapenko: I had no answers |url=https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/Tennis_Stories/127322/-dejected-cori-gauff-after-surprise-ao-loss-to-jelena-ostapenko-i-had-no-answers-/ |access-date=2023-01-23 |website=TennisWorldUSA.com |date=January 23, 2023 |archive-date=February 7, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230207180631/https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/Tennis_Stories/127322/-dejected-cori-gauff-after-surprise-ao-loss-to-jelena-ostapenko-i-had-no-answers-/ |url-status=live }}</ref> At the [[2023 Qatar Total Open|Qatar Ladies Open]], Gauff reached the quarterfinals after defeating two-time champion [[Petra Kvitová]] in the second round.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Gauff bests Kvitova in Doha; Bencic pulls off comeback vs. Azarenka |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/3065973/gauff-bests-kvitova-in-doha-bencic-pulls-off-comeback-vs-azarenka |date=February 15, 2023 |access-date=2023-02-25 |publisher=Women's Tennis Association |archive-date=February 24, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230224061337/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/3065973/gauff-bests-kvitova-in-doha-bencic-pulls-off-comeback-vs-azarenka |url-status=live }}</ref> At the same tournament in doubles, Gauff and Jessica Pegula defended their title, defeating [[Lyudmyla Kichenok]] and Jeļena Ostapenko in a three-set match.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Gauff, Pegula successfully defend Doha doubles title |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/3069435/gauff-pegula-successfully-defend-doha-doubles-title |date=February 17, 2023 |access-date=2023-02-25 |publisher=Women's Tennis Association |archive-date=February 18, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230218210938/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/3069435/gauff-pegula-successfully-defend-doha-doubles-title |url-status=live }}</ref> At [[2023 Dubai Tennis Championships|Dubai]], Gauff reached the semifinals by defeating Madison Keys in the quarterfinals, before losing to Iga Świątek.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Swiatek improves to 6–0 vs. Gauff to reach Dubai final |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/3080620/swiatek-improves-to-6-0-vs-gauff-to-reach-dubai-final |access-date=2023-02-25 |publisher=Women's Tennis Association |date=February 24, 2023 |archive-date=February 25, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230225144751/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/3080620/swiatek-improves-to-6-0-vs-gauff-to-reach-dubai-final |url-status=live }}</ref> At [[2023 BNP Paribas Open|Indian Wells]], Gauff lost in the quarterfinals to second seed and eventual runner-up, Aryna Sabalenka. In [[2023 Miami Open|Miami]], Gauff lost against 27th seed [[Anastasia Potapova]] in the third round. In doubles at the same tournament, Gauff won her fifth overall and third WTA 1000 team title with her partner Jessica Pegula. They became the first all-American duo to win the Miami Open doubles title in 22 years, defeating Leylah Fernandez and [[Taylor Townsend]] in the final.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/3134118/gauff-pegula-win-miami-open-doubles-5th-team-title | title=Gauff, Pegula win Miami Open doubles; fifth team title | website=WTA | date=April 2, 2023 | access-date=April 2, 2023 | archive-date=April 2, 2023 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230402224639/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/3134118/gauff-pegula-win-miami-open-doubles-5th-team-title | url-status=live }}</ref>

In August, Gauff won the [[Washington Open (tennis)|Washington Open]] title, beating Maria Sakkari in the final.<ref>{{cite web | title=Gauff defeats Sakkari to win Washington D.C. title | url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/3619064/gauff-defeats-sakkari-to-win-washington-d-c-title | work=WTA Tennis | date= August 6, 2023 | access-date=7 August 2023 | archive-date=August 7, 2023 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230807032807/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/3619064/gauff-defeats-sakkari-to-win-washington-d-c-title | url-status=live }}</ref> It was Gauff's first [[WTA 500]] singles title, and her biggest singles title to date. She became the first teenager to win the tournament.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://twitter.com/OptaAce/status/1688281168318496768 |title=Archived copy |access-date=August 6, 2023 |archive-date=August 6, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230806221905/https://twitter.com/OptaAce/status/1688281168318496768 |url-status=live }}</ref> Gauff won her first [[WTA 1000 tournaments|WTA 1000]] title at the [[2023 Western & Southern Open|2023 Cincinnati Open]], defeating world No. 1 Iga Świątek in the semifinals and world No. 10, [[Karolína Muchová]], in the final.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Coco Gauff bests Muchova in Cincinnati to win first WTA 1000 title |url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/3644720/coco-gauff-bests-muchova-in-cincinnati-to-win-first-wta-1000-title |date=August 20, 2023 |access-date=2023-09-07 |website=Women's Tennis Association |language=en |archive-date=August 21, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230821060442/https://www.wtatennis.com/news/3644720/coco-gauff-bests-muchova-in-cincinnati-to-win-first-wta-1000-title |url-status=live }}</ref>

In September, Gauff won the [[2023 US Open – Women's singles|US Open]], her first major singles title, beating world No. 2 Aryna Sabalenka in three sets and becoming the first American teenager to win the US Open since Serena Williams in 1999.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Futterman |first=Matthew |date=2023-09-09 |title=U.S. Open Women's Final: Live Updates: Coco Gauff Wins First Grand Slam Title |language=en-US |newspaper=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/live/2023/09/09/sports/us-open-gauff-sabalenka |access-date=2023-09-09 |issn=0362-4331 |archive-date=September 9, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230909230326/https://www.nytimes.com/live/2023/09/09/sports/us-open-gauff-sabalenka |url-status=live }}</ref> As a result, she reached world No. 3 in the rankings on 11 September 2023 and was nominated at the [[Laureus World Sports Awards]] for [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Laureus_World_Sports_Award_for_Breakthrough_of_the_Year&wvprov=sticky-header Breakthrough of the Year].<ref>{{cite news |title=Rankings Watch: Sabalenka, Gauff-Pegula duo headline historic shakeup|url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/3679827/rankings-watch-sabalenka-gauff-pegula-duo-headline-historic-shakeup |date=September 11, 2023|access-date=11 September 2023 |publisher=WTA}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-04-08 |title=Novak Djokovic, Iga Swiatek and Coco Gauff nominated at the 25th Laureus World Sports Awards : All you need to know |url=https://www.tennisclubhouse.ca/en/post/novak-djokovic-iga-swiatek-and-coco-gauff-nominated-at-the-25th-laureus-world-sports-awards-all-y |access-date=2024-04-09 |website=Tennis Clubhouse |language=en}}</ref>

Gauff and Pegula returned to the world No. 1 doubles ranking on 23 October 2023, after qualifying for the [[2023 WTA Finals]] as a pair and also individually, becoming the first players to qualify in both disciplines in back-to-back years since [[Sara Errani]] in 2012–13.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/3749540/road-to-the-wta-finals-gauff-and-pegula | title=Road to the WTA Finals: Gauff and Pegula |website=WTA Tennis|date=October 23, 2023}}</ref>

===2024: WTA Finals singles and French Open doubles title===
{{main|2024 Coco Gauff tennis season}}
At the [[2024 Italian Open (tennis)|Italian Open]] she reached the semifinal for the second time at this tournament and second at the WTA 1000 level for the season defeating Magdalena Fręch, Jaqueline Cristian, Paula Badosa and seventh seed [[Zheng Qinwen]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/4009979/gauff-holds-off-badosa-in-three-sets-advances-to-rome-quarterfinals|title=Gauff holds off Badosa in three sets; advances to Rome quarterfinals|website=WTAtennis.com|date=13 May 2024}}</ref> With the win, she passed [[Caroline Wozniacki]] for the most WTA 1000 wins before turning 21. She lost to world No. 1 Iga Świątek, in straight sets.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/4017300/swiatek-ousts-gauff-in-rome-into-second-consecutive-wta-1000-final|title=Swiatek ousts Gauff in Rome; into second consecutive WTA 1000 final|website=WTAtennis.com|date=16 May 2024}}</ref> At the same tournament, partnering [[Erin Routliffe]], she reached a consecutive final in doubles.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/4018636/gauff-routliffe-to-meet-italian-hopes-errani-paolini-in-rome-doubles-final|title=Gauff, Routliffe to meet Italian hopes Errani, Paolini in Rome doubles fina|website=WTAtennis.com|date=17 May 2024}}</ref>

At the [[2024 French Open – Women's doubles|2024 French Open]] with new partner [[Katerina Siniaková]], she lifted her first Grand Slam tournament doubles trophy defeating 11th seeds [[Sara Errani]] and [[Jasmine Paolini]] in the final.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/coco-gauff-is-a-grand-slam-champion-in-singles-and-doubles-exceeding-her-own-expectations|title=Coco Gauff is a Grand Slam champion in singles and doubles, exceeding her own expectations|website=WTAtennis.com|date=9 June 2024|accessdate=13 June 2024}}</ref> In singles, also at Roland Garros, she reached the semifinals and was defeated by eventual champion [[Iga Swiatek]], but despite the loss reached a new career-high ranking of world No. 2 in singles on 10 June 2024.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/4036039/rankings-watch-gauff-overtakes-sabalenka-at-no-2-paolini-into-the-top-10|title=Rankings Watch: Gauff overtakes Sabalenka at No.2; Paolini into the Top 10|website=WTAtennis.com|date=10 June 2024|accessdate=13 June 2024}}</ref>

At the [[2024 Wimbledon Championships]], Gauff went out in the fourth round to [[Emma Navarro]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/tennis/articles/cw0yqgvyx19o|title=Gauff's Wimbledon woes continue in Navarro defeat|date=July 7, 2024 |publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=7 July 2024}}</ref> Gauff was chosen by her Olympic teammates to be the female flag-bearer for the United States at the opening ceremony of the [[2024 Summer Olympics]] in Paris, alongside [[LeBron James]]. She became the youngest athlete to be so honored.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/tennis/articles/cjerp400zepo|title=Tennis player Gauff to be US women's flagbearer|date=July 24, 2024 |publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=24 July 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/olympics/coco-gauff-olympics-paris-opening-ceremony-b2585098.html|title=Coco Gauff picked as Team USA flag bearer joining LeBron James at Olympics opening ceremony|work=The Independent|first=James|last=Liddell|date=July 24, 2024 |accessdate=24 July 2024}}</ref> In singles, she lost in the third round to [[Donna Vekić]] in straight sets.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.eurosport.com/tennis/olympic-games-paris-2024/2024/coco-gauff-out-paris-2024-tennis-donna-vekic_sto20022982/story.shtml|title=Paris 2024 Olympic Games: Coco Gauff suffers controversial loss to Donna Vekic to exit women's singles|first=Charlie|last=Allenby|publisher=Eurosport|date=30 July 2024|access-date=30 July 2024}}</ref> At the [[2024 China Open – Women's singles|2024 China Open]], she became the youngest China Open champion in 14 years after defeating Karolina Muchova in the final. It was her second [[WTA 1000]] title and eighth career singles title. Gauff will be the second American champion in Beijing, following Serena Williams title runs in 2004 and 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/4143337/gauff-storms-past-muchova-to-win-china-open-second-title-of-2024|title=Gauff storms past Muchova to win China Open, second title of 2024|publisher=Women's Tennis Association|date= October 6, 2024|access-date=6 October 2024}}</ref> 

On November 9, 2024, Gauff won the [[2024 WTA Finals – Singles|2024 WTA Finals]] singles champion,<ref>{{Cite news |last= |first= |date=9 November 2024 |title=Coco Gauff completes dream run to become youngest to win WTA Finals in 20 years |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2024/11/09/sport/coco-gauff-wta-finals-zheng-qinwen-spt-intl/index.html |access-date=9 November 2024 |work=CNN |language=en }}</ref> becoming the youngest player to win the [[WTA Finals]] since Maria Sharapova in 2004<ref>{{Cite news |last= |first= |date=10 November 2024 |title=Coco Gauff wins WTA Finals, youngest since Sharapova |url=https://www.northweststar.com.au/story/8815442/coco-gauff-wins-wta-finals-youngest-since-sharapova/ |access-date=10 November 2024 |work=The North West Star |language=en }}</ref> and the first American to win the finals since Serena Williams in 2014.<ref>{{Cite news |last= |first= |date=9 November 2024 |title=Coco Gauff wins Women's Tennis Association Finals, first American to do so since Serena Williams |url=https://www.wusa9.com/article/sports/coco-gauff-china-united-states-serena-williams-tennis-wta-womens-association-finals/65-de3ca9c8-7b31-4975-8bfd-956d48c00d64 |access-date=9 November 2024 |work=WUSA9 |language=en }}</ref> She beat [[Iga Świątek|Iga Swiatek]], the No. 2 seed and defending champion of the WTA final in [[Riyadh]].<ref>{{Cite news |last=Carayol |first=Tumaini |date=2024-11-05 |title=Gauff storms to second-ever win over Swiatek at WTA Finals in Riyadh |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2024/nov/05/tennis-coco-gauff-iga-swiatek-wta-finals |access-date=2024-11-06 |work=The Guardian |language=en-GB |issn=0261-3077}}</ref> She then defeated Sabalenka in the semis and Zheng Qinwen in the finals to capture her first year-end singles championship title.<ref>{{cite web |title=Gauff wins WTA Finals after epic battle with Zheng|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/tennis/articles/cj6kx7wx103o |website=BBC Sport |date=9 November 2024}}</ref>

==Playing style and coaching==
Gauff's favorite surface is hard, and she describes her playing style as aggressive as possible with a big serve. She depends on her quickness and athleticism to keep her in any point, and describes herself as a "fighter".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wtatennis.com/players/328560/coco-gauff#bio|title =Coco Gauff Bio|publisher=Hologic WTA Tour.|accessdate=11 July 2024}}</ref>

From July 2023 to September 2024 her coach was [[Brad Gilbert]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wtatennis.com/news/4121808/coco-gauff-and-coach-brad-gilbert-part-ways|title=Coco Gauff and coach Brad Gilbert part ways|publisher=Women's Tennis Association|accessdate=18 September 2024}}</ref> In September 2024 Gauff hired coach Matt Daly.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/coco-gauff-adds-matt-daly-to-coaching-team-aims-to-work-on-serve-ahead-of-china-open|title=Coco Gauff adds Matt Daly to coaching team, aims to work on serve ahead of China Open|website=Tennis.com|accessdate=28 September 2024}}</ref>

web|url=https://wlmtennis.com/roland-garrosfashion-palette/|title=Roland Garros…Fashion Palette|first=Cheryl |last=Jones|author2= Mark Winters|date=4 June 2021|work=WLM Tennis|access-date=17 December ==Personal life==
Gauff is a [[Christianity|Christian]]. Since she was eight years old, she has prayed with her father before every match that she and her opponent would be safe. After winning the Cincinnati Open in August 2023, she said: "… I'd like to thank my Lord and Savior, Jesus Christ. I spent a lot of nights alone, crying trying to figure it out. I still have a lot to figure out, but I thank Him for covering me." After winning her first Grand Slam title in September 2023, she said: "… I don't pray for results, I just ask that I get the strength to give it my all and whatever happens happens. I'm so blessed in this life."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Claybourn |first1=Cole |title=Coco Gauff claims first U.S. Open title, kneels in prayer to give thanks to God |url=https://sportsspectrum.com/sport/tennis/2023/09/10/coco-gauff-us-open-prayer-thanks-to-god/ |website=Sports Spectrum |date=September 10, 2023 |access-date=11 September 2023}}</ref>

Gauff's tennis idols are Serena and Venus Williams. "Serena Williams has always been my idol...and Venus," she has said. "They are the reason why I wanted to pick up a tennis racquet."<ref name=upi/> Gauff first met Serena when she won the Little Mo national tournament at the age of eight, and later met her again to film a commercial for [[Delta Air Lines]] and at the Mouratoglou Academy.<ref name=gauff-hopes/> After defeating Venus Williams at Wimbledon in 2019, Gauff expressed her respect when they shook hands at the net. "I was just telling her thank you for everything she's done for the sport," Gauff said. "She's been an inspiration for many people. I was just really telling her thank you."<ref name=nyt-venus/>

Gauff stated in 2020 that she had experienced [[Depression (mood)|depression]] and stress related to her sporting career, though her parents clarified that she was not diagnosed with depression in the clinical sense, and had not sought medical attention relating to her psychological well-being.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Clarey|first=Christopher|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/19/sports/tennis/coco-gauff.html|title=Coco Gauff's Emotional Struggles: What Her Parents Saw|date=2020-04-19|newspaper=The New York Times|access-date=2020-04-20|issn=0362-4331|archive-date=April 21, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200421010108/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/19/sports/tennis/coco-gauff.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

Gauff is a fan of [[anime]], including [[My Hero Academia]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Coco has a simple plan to get ready for her next match: watch some anime |url=https://twitter.com/usopen/status/1699969027974516822 |website=Twitter |publisher=US Open Tennis |date=September 8, 2023|access-date=10 September 2023}}</ref>

In July 2023, Gauff and actress [[Storm Reid]] helped fund a new playground and purple-painted tennis courts in East Atlanta's [[Brownwood Park]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.wsbtv.com/news/local/atlanta/atlanta-park-gets-an-upgrade-thanks-local-celebrities/SPMEP32OUJD7JL62ZRVAAHEBKQ/ | title=Atlanta park gets an upgrade thanks to tennis star Coco Gauff, actress Storm Reid | date=July 24, 2023 }}</ref>
